title: A number theory problem by Tan Peng
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a !+ b !+c != d !,"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a, b, c, d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are all positive integers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the number of possible solutions "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a, b, c, d)?"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"WLOG "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a\ \leq b \leq c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d > c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" since factorials is a monotonicaly increasing function. We have
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}
d! &= a!+b!+c!\\
&\leq 3c!\\
\dfrac{d!}{c!} &\leq 3\\
\dfrac{d!}{c!} &= 2, 3\\
\implies (d,c) &= (3,2), (2,1), (2,0)
\end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We note that the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d=2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" cannot work since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n! \geq 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus, the only possible solution is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d=3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c=2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which yields "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=b=2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus, the only solution is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(2,2,2,3)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

But since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a!, b!, c! \ge 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the sum has to be at least "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d=2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is not possible.

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Something needs to be said to the effect that d > max(a,b,c).  Also the first sentence needs to be generalized for d > 4.  My first point might be too nitpicky but I don't think my second one is.  (Besides, it takes as little effort write the argument once for all d > 3 as it does to write the argument once for d=4.) ("For d > 3, 3*(d-1)! < d!").

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since  {"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"}are all positive integers.Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha!,\beta!,\gamma!\,\delta!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are all positive and {"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha!,\beta!,\gamma!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"}"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"<\delta! "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha!<\beta!<\gamma!<\delta!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"                                                                                                                                                                                                                "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\gamma!(\alpha)(\alpha-1)(\alpha-2)...(\alpha-\gamma+1)(\alpha-\gamma)+(\beta)(\beta-1)(\beta-2)...(\beta+-\gamma+1)(\beta-\gamma)+1=\delta!"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
When "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha!,\beta!,\gamma!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are equal."},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\gamma!(\alpha)(\alpha-1)(\alpha-2)...(\alpha-\gamma+1)(\alpha-\gamma)+(\beta)(\beta-1)(\beta-2)...(\beta+-\gamma+1)(\beta-\gamma)+1=3\gamma!"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"                                                                                                                                                                                                                          "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3\gamma!=\delta!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Then the only different factor of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\gamma!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\delta !"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ,When"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\delta! =3!, \gamma!= 2!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the equality holds. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
To prove that no other solutions when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\delta<3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\delta>3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Case 1: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\delta<3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"                                                                                                                                                                               We know that 2!=2 since 2 can only be written as 2 positive integers that is 1+1 it will not satisfy the equation.                               The case for 1! is also similar as above. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Case 2: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\delta>3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"                                                                                                                                                                                                  We know that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n!=n(n-1)!"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" Since n>3 and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3(n-1)!< n!=n(n-1)!"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" we could show that the sum of three factorials that is smaller than  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\delta!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\delta>3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is impossible."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Without loss of generality let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a\leq b\leq c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a!+b!+c!\leq 3c!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". So the extra factor that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has over "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is 3 or less. Note that there is no integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k!=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Therefore "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c<d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d=2 \text{ or } 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c=1 \text{ or } 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There are only 4 possibilities left to check."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1!+1!+1!=3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which is not a factorial."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1!+1!+2!=4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which is not a factorial."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1!+2!+2!=5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which is not a factorial."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2!+2!+2!=3\cdot 2!=3!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which is a valid solution and therefore the only valid solution. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note: this is pretty much identical to Sharky's solution but I tried to express it more naturally. The "without loss of generality" statement and the ordering of the variables are extremely useful and common tricks that reduce the complexity of the problem. They also make it easy to express the next idea that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can't be more than 3 times the largest term of the left hand side. Again, this inequality trick is another common way to reduce the scale of the solution space. Now, fortunately the solution space is so small you can use even inefficient and unintelligent ideas to find the solution. In conclusion, there is a standard bag of tricks built by experience that you should always think about using to reduce the complexity and solution space of a problem before you need to try to be clever."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            That would mean that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3d!=d!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since there is no non-negative integer whose factorial is 0 or infinite, this implies "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c\neq d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Solution "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2!+2!+2!=3!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the only solution in which "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=b=c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", as every other situation in which "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=b=c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a!+b!+c!=3a!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is only a factorial if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, every other solution must involve at least two distinct positive integers among "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a,b,c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Suppose, without loss of generality, that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the smallest value between a,b,c. Also suppose, without loss of generality, that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b\ge c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". That being the case, there exist integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k>0,l \ge 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=a+k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c=a+l"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In that way, we have that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a!+b!+c!=a!+(a+k)!+(a+l)!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is only a valid solution if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+\frac{(a+k)!}{a!}+\frac{(a+l)!}{a!}=\frac{(a+m)!}{a!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m>k,l"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+\frac{(a+k)!}{a!}+\frac{(a+l)!}{a!} \le 2\frac{(a+k)!}{a!}+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Also note that  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{(a+m)!}{a!} \ge (a+m)\frac{(a+k)!}{a!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", but since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a+k) >1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we have that
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a+m) \ge 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", implying that it is impossible for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+\frac{(a+k)!}{a!}+\frac{(a+l)!}{a!}=\frac{(a+m)!}{a!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m>k \ge l"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

So, I found the answer 1..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Which is the smallest number which is divisible by "},{"type":"text","text":"all numbers 1-10","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"?\n(Hint : Find their "},{"type":"text","text":"LCM","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":")"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The LCM of these numbers is the answer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 = 1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2 = 2"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3 = 3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 = 2 x 2"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5 = 5"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6 = 2 x 3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7 = 7"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8 = 2 x 2x 2"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9 = 3 x 3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10 = 2 x 5"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"LCM = 2 x 2 x 2 x 3 x 3 x 5 x 7 = 2520"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The answer is 2520","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5n>10285^{n} > 10^{28}5n>1028","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5n>(5×2)285^{n} > (5 \times 2)^{28}5n>(5×2)28","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5n>528×2285^{n} > 5^{28} \times 2^{28}5n>528×228","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5n−28>2285^{n-28} > 2^{28}5n−28>228","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^{3} < 2^{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Have both sides multiplied to the fourth power, then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^{12} < 2^{28}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, "},{"type":"text","text":"513>2285^{13} > 2^{28}513>228","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"text","text":"n - 28 = 13, then n = 41","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                            If a < b, than how can we say 5a > b ..
Above, a = 5^12 and b = 2^28

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Why would the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^{4} > 2^{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" statement be enough? It doesn't seem it covers it fully. I'm not sure there's a proof that goes directly to 13 as a sum to the 28. One way to do this would be to note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^{14} > 2^{28}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^{28} = (2^{2})^{14} = 4^{14}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5 > 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then you're left with either 13 or 14, and you can calculate to test it.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Just because "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^{12}<2^{28}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" doesn't mean that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^{13}>2^{28}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". To complete your proof, state that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^4>2^7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and multiply the inequalities "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^4\cdot5^3\cdot5^3\cdot5^3=5^{13}>2^7\cdot2^7\cdot2^7\cdot2^7=2^{28}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We simply apply the logarithmic method."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"so,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^n > 10^28"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(log both the sides)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= log (5^n) > log (10^28)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= n (log 5) > 28"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= n > 28 / (log 5)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= n > 40.0589..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, n = 41 is the minimum"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            You need to note the monotonicity of the logarithm function to verify the transformation of the inequality.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Taking log 10 of both sides, we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n \log 5>28 \log 10=28 \Rightarrow n>\frac{28}{\log 5} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \log 5 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is just nearly under "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{7}{10} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n>40.some "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so the least integer that satisfies this is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \lceil 40.some \rceil "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is creary (hopefully?) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \boxed{41} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(Note that an exacter (?) value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \log 5 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can be found using a calculator, and that it is a good idea to memorise that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \log 5 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is slightly under "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{7}{10} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (if you haven't already))"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For 5^n > 10^ 28,
we require n log 5 > 28( log 10 )
                                  > 28 * 1
          therefore n > 28/log 5 > 28/.7 > 40
Therefore smallest n = 41"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I found a way to improve this solution a bit..The title of the question solves the problem."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^n>10^{28}\implies 5^n>5^{28}\cdot 2^{28}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This implies that we are looking for a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^k>2^{28}=(2^7)^4=(128)^4=(125+3)^4=(5^3+3)^4=
(5^{12}+4*5^9*3+6*5^6*3^2+
4*5^3*3^3+3^4)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This considerably reduces the number of cases to check,as the left hand side must be greater than the first term of the expansion("},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^{12})"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By taking log on both the sides, we get"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"},{"type":"text","text":"log5 > 28","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"log10"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n*log5 > 28"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n > 28 / log5"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n > 40.2"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence n = 41"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let 5^n=10^28
then take Lin for both sides .. you will get n  * lin 5=28 * lin 10
then n = 40.05894363
add (0.94105637) to get the integer of 41"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^{n} > 10^{28)      Take log for both sides","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"nlog5 > 28log10              divide by log5 (log10 = 1)","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n >  28/{log5}   which is approximately equals 40","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"then the least integer value of n = 41","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Well, obviously "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5^{n} > 10^{28} \Rightarrow 5^{n-28} > 2^{28} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Now, if we apply the natural log function on both sides we get"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n = \left \lceil 28 + \frac{\ln2^{28}}{\ln5} \right \rceil = 41 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
